channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: Some faculty leaders on our campus proposed taking a substantial step in this direction maybe a decade ago, and the administration said, essentially, "Oh, no, we couldn't afford that." https://t.co/AMTphtw8rv
South Bend, Indiana, right now. https://t.co/w0JINdLJTx
The Wall Street Journal's view of Mr. Trump on the day after the insurrection. "In the name of God, go!" https://t.co/QRgtdMwle4
Just remembering how IN-2nd's @RepWalorski behaved after the crisis--her silence speaks and speaks. https://t.co/6c4URoTnrR

“There was never an indication of interest in what the actual facts were.” Don’t call it crazy, call it a workable approach to everyday life that is only available to the powerful. Useful for gaming every system. Article by AP’s ⁦@DavidKlepper⁩. https://t.co/do2ymFPgB9
@davewiner More than one kind of close call…

Listening to yesterday's hearing, I had the feeling that the Trump inner circle might have been satisfied to provoke ongoing violence that justified martial law and putting off the transfer of power indefinitely.

After many years in office, IN-2nd’s @RepWalorski is still looking down at her notes most of the time here, like a person who doesn’t bother about details, can’t go into depth on issues, and doesn’t know what she thinks beyond the slogans. Walorski’s slogans aren’t good enough. https://t.co/gQJdu8xtA1
“A thing is right when it tends to preserve the integrity, stability and beauty of the biotic community. It is wrong when it tends otherwise.” —Aldo Leopold

There should be a week-long unit in school each year about the difference between living well and merely going through the motions. https://t.co/mbMrgBD3wU
There should be a week-long unit in school each year about ways in which people eventually look back at their lives and see how ignorant and cruel they sometimes were. https://t.co/ha8wGq4iFu
Assault rifles in U.S. daily life: "We will continue to live with them because they are a near-perfect companion to minority rule." https://t.co/YDMUTEicBX

IN-2nd's @RepWalorski / @JackieWalorski seems not to have heard about the Jan 6 hearings, or maybe she can't think of anything useful to say, or more likely she's part of the GOP plan to distract Americans from the shameful findings.

The January 6th committee: Nowhere near aggressive enough about social media when facing a Republican party that routinely throws up smoke screens on anything related to truth and fact. https://t.co/CP6g3kPKqc
“Is there anyone in Trump World who isn't trying [to] fleece the Deplorables?” —Ann Coulter
@herdyshepherd1 We need a sort of Whole Earth Catalog of methods and methods and methods.
“If a complaint can leave a trail as well as be a tale, a complaint can be how we know where to go to find each other.” https://t.co/zkRvVEjLJf
@herdyshepherd1 Moving them Missouri-style!
If something I owned and cared about had lost 2/3 of its value since I pushed back from dinner last Thanksgiving, I'd be freaking out. Cryptocurrency Global Charts. https://t.co/TpHy7f4Zos
I wonder if Einstein overstated the case here . . . https://t.co/dStOnyPUOc
“None of these men who worked for Trump opened their mouths at the time.” https://t.co/sMdNy3yV8f
Wordle 360 2/6 🟨🟨🟨🟨🟨 🟩🟩🟩🟩🟩 Well, that was different…
@JordanDavisPoet I am most fond of number 4.

Writers often use commonplace books to record quotations that they may want to come back to someday and build on. For writers who don't have much of an audience on Twitter, Twitter itself acts like an easy-to-write-in but not-easy-to-read-later commonplace book. So, not so good.
"Little lands on the borders of a great empire were always hateful to the lords of the great empire." https://t.co/IZ8OhW99qw

“Most of her friends, who seemed to her ordinarily hard-working, anxious, and hopeful, people, could lay claim to being disowned or prayed for, in some disappointed home. —Alice Munro, “Spelling” #SundaySentence @MunroQuotes
